Course.Title: MGT OF CORPORATE FINANCE I
Course.Description: Management of Corporate Finance I is an entry-level undergraduate finance course. The course offers introduction to basics modern financial theory and practice of corporate finance. In particular, the course explores topics such as objectives of financial management, financial statement analysis, time value of money, risk and return, valuation of bonds and stocks, and fundamentals of capital budgeting.

Sections.CourseDescription: Management of Corporate Finance I is an entry-level undergraduate finance course. MeetingsDisplay: Monday, Wednesday 1:00 PM - 2:15 PM COLL BUSINESS&PUBLIC MGT A201 (Lecture)
Sections.Comments: WENZHOU KEAN STUDENTS ONLY. sophomore ACCT only

Course.Title: CORPORATE FINANCE II
Course.Description: A continuation of FIN 3310 with emphasis in long-term management decisions. In particular, the course focuses on such topics as equilibrium asset pricing models, cost of capital, risk analysis and real options theory in corporate decision-making cash flow estimation, and optimal corporate structure and dividend policies.

Sections.CourseDescription: A continuation of FIN 3310 with emphasis in long-term management decisions. In particular, the course focuses on such topics as equilibrium asset pricing models, cost of capital, risk analysis and real options theory in corporate decision-making cash flow estimation, and optimal corporate structure and dividend policies.

Sections.Comments: WENZHOU KEAN STUDENTS ONLY. BUSINESS STUDENTS ONLY Junior FIN first

Course.Title: PREP & ANLYSIS FINANCIAL STMTS
Course.Description: Fundamental financial analysis starts with the information found in a company's financial reports. Basic financial statements provide a foundation that enables the users to better understand information gathered so they can arrive at a decision or recommendation. A central focus is to evaluate the company's ability to earn a return on its capital, to grow its operations with profits, and to generate enough cash to meet obligations and pursue opportunities. This course is designed to take the students to evaluate the past, current, and potential performance and financial position of a company for the purpose of making investment, credit, and other economic decisions.

MeetingsDisplay: Wednesday, Friday 11:30 AM - 12:45 PM COLL BUSINESS&PUBLIC MGT C323 (Lecture)
Sections.Comments: WENZHOU KEAN STUDENTS ONLY. BUSINESS STUDENTS ONLY ACCT senior, FIN junior/senior first
Sections.Title: PREP & ANLYSIS FINANCIAL STMTS

Course.Title: INVESTMENTS
Course.Description: The objective of this course is to study the basic principles of investments suitable for individuals and for business organizations. The course covers in details topics such as analysis and valuation of securities, issues on market efficiency and behavioral finance, derivatives, and the creation and management of portfolios.

Course.Title: FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS & MKTS
Course.Description: The course examines the role of money and capital markets in the economy, and the effects of the Federal Reserve's monetary and regulatory policies.  The course focuses on the working of various financial markets and how financial institutions and other users interact with financial markets.  Topics include interest rates; term structure of interest rates; money and capital markets; innovations in capital markets; credit risk and asset and liability management; international financial markets; currency fluctuations; and management of currency risk.

Sections.CourseDescription: The course examines the role of money and capital markets in the economy, and the effects of the Federal Reserve's monetary and regulatory policies. Course.Title: BASIC FRENCH I
Course.Description: Introduction to French, focusing on the relation- ship between language and culture.  Emphasis on developing grammatical competence and communicative skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing in the target language.  Required laboratory component.  Six credit hours (in sequence) of one foreign language must be successfully completed to receive three credit hours toward the General Education Disciplinary Requirement.

Sections.Title: BASIC FRENCH I

Course.Title: BASIC FRENCH I
Course.Description: Introduction to French, focusing on the relation- ship between language and culture.  Emphasis on developing grammatical competence and communicative skills: listening, speaking, reading, and writing in the target language.  Required laboratory component.  Six credit hours (in sequence) of one foreign language must be successfully completed to receive three credit hours toward the General Education Disciplinary Requirement.
